''[http://www.tagesspiegel.de/berlin/moschee-in-wilmersdorf-mit-kuppel-komplett/252118.html Moschee in Wilmersdorf: Mit Kuppel komplett]'', 29 August 2001, Retrieved 27 January 2016</ref>
==Islamic organisations== Only a minority of the Muslims residing in Germany are members of religious associations.
===Sunni=== *'''[[Diyanet İşleri Türk İslam Birliği]] (DİTİB)''': German branch of the Turkish Presidency for Religious Affairs, [[Cologne]]. As of 2016, the Turkish government funds and provides staff for 900 of Germany's roughly 3000 mosques run by DİTİB.<ref name="Faultlines">{{cite news|title=Old Faultlines|url=https://www.economist.com/news/europe/21703296-tensions-rise-turkey-they-spill-over-germany-old-faultlines|accessdate=9 August 2016|publisher=[[The Economist]]|date=6 August 2016}}</ref> *'''Islamische Gemeinschaft [[Milli Görüş]]''': close to the Islamist Saadet Partisi in Turkey, Kerpen near Cologne *'''Islamische Gemeinschaft Jamaat un-Nur''' ([[:de:Islamische Gemeinschaft Jama' at-un Nur|de]]): German branch of the Risale-i Nur Society ([[Said Nursi]]) *'''[[Islamic Community of Germany|Islamische Gemeinschaft in Deutschland]]''' organization of [[Arab Muslims]] close to the [[Muslim Brotherhood]], [[Frankfurt]]
In addition there are numerous local associations without affiliation to any of these organisations. Two organisations have been banned in 2002 because their programme was judged as contrary to the constitution: The "[[Hizb ut-Tahrir]]" and the so-called "[[Caliphate State]]" founded by Cemalettin Kaplan and later led by his son [[Metin Kaplan]].
===Shia=== *'''[[Islamische Gemeinschaft der schiitischen Gemeinden Deutschlands]] (IGS)''': Head organization that unite all [[Shia Islam|Shiite]] mosques and associations in Germany, with being the [[Islamic Centre Hamburg]] the most important Shia mosque in Germany. *'''[[Al-Mustafa Institut Berlin]]''': A branch of the [[Al-Mustafa International University]] in [[Qom|Qum]], [[Iran]] to Islamic theology to students in Germany and Europe.
===Ahmadiyya=== * '''[[Ahmadiyya Muslim Jama'at|Ahmadiyya Muslim Jamaat Deutschland K.d.ö.R.]]''': German branch of the worldwide Ahmadiyya Community. There is no ethnicity or race associated with this community although most of the members of the community residing in Germany are of Pakistani origin. The Ahmadiyya Community was established in Germany in 1923 in Berlin and is one of the largest in Europe. Communities exist in Baden-Württemberg, Lower Saxony, North Rhine-Westphalia, Hesse and Bremen.<ref>Ahmadiyya Muslim Mosques Around the World, pg. 44</ref> * '''[[Lahore Ahmadiyya Movement for the Propagation of Islam|Lahore Ahmadiyya Movement]]''': German branch of the worldwide Lahore Ahmadiyya Movement.
===Liberal Islam=== * [[Ibn Ruschd-Goethe mosque]] in Berlin was founded by [[Seyran Ateş]]. The liberal mosque has been condemned by the Turkish religious authority and the Egyptian Fatwa Council at the [[Al-Azhar University]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.welt.de/politik/deutschland/article165832629/Die-meisten-liberalen-Muslime-haben-Angst.html|title=Ibn-Rushd-Goethe-Moschee: Seyran Ates sieht liberale Muslime bedroht|last=Breyton|first=Ricarda|date=2017-06-23|work=DIE WELT|access-date=2018-04-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/jun/25/ibn-rushd-goethe-mosque-berlin-seyran-ates-egypt-fatwa-burqa-niqab|title=Liberal Berlin mosque to stay open despite fatwa from Egypt|last=Oltermann|first=Philip|date=2017-06-25|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-04-30}}</ref> *[[Ibn Rushd Prize for Freedom of Thought]]
=== Wahhabism === * [[King Fahd Academy (Germany)|King Fahd Academy]], sponsored by [[Saudi Arabia]]. ==Controversies== As elsewhere [[Islam in Western Europe|in Western Europe]], the rapid growth of the Muslim community in Germany has led to social tensions and political controversy, partly connected to [[Islamic extremism]], and more generally due to the perceived difficulties of [[multiculturalism]] and fears of ''[[Überfremdung]]''. <!-- A [[December 2010]] poll by [[Ifop]], published by the [[French newspapers|French newspaper]] [[Le Monde]] in [[January 2011]], said that 42% of the [[Germans|German]] population regard [[Muslims]] in [[Germany]] as a threat to their [[Nation|national identity]], 75% regard Muslims in [[Germany]] as poorly integrated, 67% blamed the "refusal" by Muslims to integrate.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ifop.com/?option=com_publication&type=poll&id=1365%5D%5Bhttp://www.ifop.com/media/poll/1365-1-study_file.pdf%5D,|title=Ifop - Regard croisé France/Allemagne sur l’Islam|author=|date=|website=www.ifop.com|accessdate=3 April 2018}}</ref> This poll has been widely criticized for not being reliable (less than 1000 people polled altought more than 80 millions people in Germany, poll by Internet without interview, biased questions).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://observatoire-des-sondages.org/L-ennemi-interieur-a-la-une-Le.html][http://observatoire-des-sondages.org/2012-la-campagne-de-desinformation.html],|title=[http://sites.radiofrance.fr/franceinter/chro/edito/?id=99736], [http://www.arretsurimages.net/vite.php?id=10041], [http://lmsi.net/Pour-100-des-musulmans-les][http://www.oumma.com/Pour-100-des-musulmans-les], [https://twitter.com/CarolineFourest/status/22580789287854080][https://twitter.com/CarolineFourest/status/22581160508923904][http://podcast.rmc.fr/channel30/20110105_bourdin_2.mp3#t=300,660][http://www.lepost.fr/article/2011/01/05/2359937_les-musulmans-pas-integres-dans-la-societe-c-est-un-ressenti-de-l-actualite.html|author=|date=|website=observatoire-des-sondages.org|accessdate=3 April 2018}}</ref> -->
=== Antisemitism === {{Side box|metadata=No|above='''Perpetrators of antisemitistic verbal<br/>harassment and physical assault'''|text={{Graph:Chart |height=150 |width=200 |xAxisTitle= |yAxisTitle=% |yAxisMin=0 |type=rect |showSymbols=yes |legend=Legend |x=harassment, assault |y1=19,25 |y1Title=Left-extremists |y2=19,19 |y2Title=Right-extremists |y3=62,81 |y3Title=Muslim group |y4=22,13 |y4Title=Christian group |y5=6,6 |y5Title=Other |colors=red,black,green,blue,grey}}|imageright=|below=Characterisation of antisemitic attackers as reported by Jewish victims. An attacker may belong to more than 1 group. Source: [[Bielefeld University]]<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://uni-bielefeld.de/ikg/daten/JuPe_Bericht_April2017.pdf|title=Jüdische Perspektiven auf Antisemitismus in Deutschland Ein Studienbericht für den Expertenrat Antisemitismus|last=Andreas Zick, Andreas Hövermann, Silke Jensen, Julia Bernstein|first=|publisher=[[Universität Bielefeld]]|year=2017|isbn=|location=Bielefeld|pages=25|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180428115221/https://uni-bielefeld.de/ikg/daten/JuPe_Bericht_April2017.pdf|archive-date=28 April 2018}}</ref>}}
A 2017 study on Jewish perspectives on [[Antisemitism in Germany#Germany|antisemitism in Germany]] by [[Bielefeld University]] found that individuals and groups belonging to the extreme right and extreme left were equally represented as perpetrators of antisemitic harassment and assault, while the largest part of the attacks were committed by Muslim assailants. The study also found that 70% of the participants feared a rise in antisemitism [[Immigration to Germany|due to immigration]] citing the antisemitic views of the refugees.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://uni-bielefeld.de/ikg/daten/JuPe_Bericht_April2017.pdf|title=Jüdische Perspektiven auf Antisemitismus in Deutschland Ein Studienbericht für den Expertenrat Antisemitismus|last=Andreas Zick, Andreas Hövermann, Silke Jensen, Julia Bernstein|first=|publisher=[[Universität Bielefeld]]|year=2017|isbn=|location=Bielefeld|pages=4|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180428115221/https://uni-bielefeld.de/ikg/daten/JuPe_Bericht_April2017.pdf|archive-date=28 April 2018}}</ref>
===In the education system=== [[File:Kopftuch im Schuldienst Deutschland.png|thumb|German States that have banned teachers from wearing headscarves (red)]] One such issue concerns the wearing of the [[hijab|head-scarf]] by teachers in schools and universities. The right to practice one's religion, stated by the teachers in question, contradicts in the view of many the [[Separation of church and state|neutral stance of the state towards religion]]. As of 2006, many of the German federal states have introduced legislation banning head-scarves for teachers. It is almost certain that in 2006 these laws will be validated as constitutional.{{cn|date=April 2018}}
In the German federal states with the exception of [[Bremen (state)|Bremen]], [[Berlin]] and [[Brandenburg]], lessons of [[religious education]] overseen by the respective religious communities are taught as an elective subject in state schools. It is being discussed whether apart from the Catholic and Protestant (and in a few schools, Jewish) religious education that currently exists, a comparable subject of Islamic religious education should be introduced as a regular part of the curricula. In several states, trials for Islamic religious education are being conducted, while in the states of Hessen, Lower-Saxony and Northrhine-Westphalia, Islamic religious education already is integrated as a regular class. The problem that the cooperation with Islamic organisations is hampered by the fact that none of them can be considered as representative of the whole Muslim community.{{cn|date=April 2018}}
===Construction of mosques and other projects=== The construction of [[mosque]]s is occasionally resisted by [[Islamophobic|anti Muslim]] reactions in the neighbourhoods concerned. For example, in 2007 an attempt by Muslims to build a large mosque in Cologne sparked a [[Cologne mosque controversy|controversy]].<ref name="georgetown2">{{cite web |url= http://berkleycenter.georgetown.edu/resources/countries/germany |title=Germany |work= |publisher=[[Berkley Center for Religion, Peace, and World Affairs]] |date= |accessdate=2011-12-29}} See drop-down essay on "Religious Freedom in Germany"</ref>
Similarly with the [[Sendlinger Mosque Controversy]],{{Citation needed|date=November 2014}} and the proposed construction of a training academy in Munich, originally called the "[[Centre for Islam in Europe, Munich]]" (ZIE-M), and later the "Munich Forum for Islam".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://wikileaks.org/plusd/cables/07MUNICH646_a.html|title=Proposed Bavarian Islamic Academy Highlights Challenges of Muslim Integration|author=|date=|publisher=|accessdate=3 April 2018|via=WikiLeaks PlusD}}</ref>
===Islamic Theological Studies=== In 2010, the German Ministry of Education and Research established Islamic Theological Studies as an academic discipline at public universities in order to train teachers for Islamic religious education and Muslim theologians. Since then, Islamic theological departments have been established at several universities, conducting research and teaching on Islam from a theological perspective.<ref>Jan Felix Engelhardt, [http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/muwo.12168/full "On Insiderism and Muslim Epistemic Communities in the German and US Study of Islam"], The Muslim World No 4, 2016, p. 740-758</ref>
===Islamic fundamentalism{{anchor|Fears_of_Islamic_fundamentalism}}=== Concerns of Islamic fundamentalism came to the fore after [[September 11, 2001]], especially with respect to Islamic fundamentalism among second- and third-generation Muslims in Germany - the [[Hamburg cell]], which included [[Mohamed Atta]], was prominent in the planning and execution of the September 11 attacks. Also the various confrontations between Islamic religious law ([[Sharia]]) and the norms of German ''[[Basic Law of the Federal Republic of Germany|Grundgesetz]]'' and culture are the subject of intense debate. German critics include both liberals and Christian groups. The former claim that Islamic fundamentalism violates basic fundamental rights whereas the latter maintain that Germany is a state and society grounded in the Christian tradition.
According to a 2007 [[Federal Ministry of the Interior, Building and Community|Federal Ministry of the Interior]] report almost half of all young Muslims in Germany support fundamentalist views. About 12% of Muslims in Germany identified with moral-religious criticism against Western societal values in combination with [[corporal punishment]] up to and including the [[Capital punishment|death penalty]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.faz.net/1.490007|title=Studie des Innenministeriums: „Viele junge Muslime gewaltbereit“|work=FAZ.NET|access-date=2018-11-24|language=de|issn=0174-4909}}</ref>
According to a 2012 poll, 72% of the [[Turks in Germany]] believe that Islam is the only true religion and 46% wish that one day more Muslims live in Germany than Christians.<ref>Liljeberg Research International: [https://d171.keyingress.de/multimedia/document/228.pdf ''Deutsch-Türkische Lebens und Wertewelten 2012''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121011112234/https://d171.keyingress.de/multimedia/document/228.pdf |date=11 October 2012 }}, July/August 2012, p. 67</ref><ref>[[Die Welt]]: [https://www.welt.de/politik/deutschland/article108659406/Tuerkische-Migranten-hoffen-auf-muslimische-Mehrheit.html ''Türkische Migranten hoffen auf muslimische Mehrheit''], 17 August 2012, retrieved 23 August 2012</ref><ref>[[The Jewish Press]]: [http://www.jewishpress.com/indepth/analysis/in-germany-turkish-muslims-hope-for-more-muslims-than-christians/2012/08/27/ ''In Germany, Turkish Muslims Hope for Muslim Majority''], 27 August 2012, retrieved 27 September 2012</ref> According to a 10-year survey by the [[University of Bielefeld]], which dealt with different aspects of attitudes to Islam, "distrust" of Islam is widespread in Germany with only 19 percent of Germans believing that Islam is compatible with German culture.<ref>[http://www.dw.de/why-germans-distrust-islam/a-16536641 Deutsche Welle: "Why Germans distrust Islam" by Ulrike Hummel] January 21, 2013</ref>
According to 2013 study by [[Social Science Research Center Berlin]], two thirds of the Muslims interviewed say that religious rules are more important to them than the laws of the country in which they live, almost 60 percent of the Muslim respondents reject homosexuals as friends; 45 percent think that Jews cannot be trusted; and an equally large group believes that the West is out to destroy Islam (Christian respondents’ answers for comparison: As many as 9 percent are openly anti-Semitic; 13 percent do not want to have homosexuals as friends; and 23 percent think that Muslims aim to destroy Western culture).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wzb.eu/en/press-release/islamic-fundamentalism-is-widely-spread|title=Islamic fundamentalism is widely spread - WZB|author=|date=|website=www.wzb.eu|accessdate=3 April 2018}}</ref>
=== Salafism === Salafists strive to live exclusively according to the Quran. According to German authorities, Salafism is incompatible with the principles codified in the Constitution of Germany, in particular democracy, the rule of law and a political order based on human rights.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.verfassungsschutz.bayern.de/islamismus/definition/erscheinungsformen/salafismus/index.html|title=Salafismus|website=www.verfassungsschutz.bayern.de|language=de|access-date=2018-07-22}}</ref> According to the [[Federal Office for the Protection of the Constitution|German security service]], the Salafist movement attracts rising numbers. In 2011 there were an estimated 3800 Salafists in Germany, which rose to 10300 in September 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.verfassungsschutz.de/de/arbeitsfelder/af-islamismus-und-islamistischer-terrorismus/was-ist-islamismus/salafistische-bestrebungen|title=Salafistische Bestrebungen Inhalte und Ziele salafistischer Ideologie|last=|first=|date=|website=BfV|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180115163049/http://www.verfassungsschutz.de/de/arbeitsfelder/af-islamismus-und-islamistischer-terrorismus/was-ist-islamismus/salafistische-bestrebungen|archive-date=15 January 2018|dead-url=|access-date=22 July 2018}}</ref> According to head of security office [[Hans-Georg Maaßen]], the Salafist scene in Germany is not dominated by any one single individual, but instead a great many persons have to be monitored.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.focus.de/politik/deutschland/gewaltbereite-islamisten-erstmals-mehr-als-10-000-salafisten-in-deutschland_id_6863813.html|title=Gewaltbereite Islamisten: Erstmals mehr als 10.000 Salafisten in Deutschland|last=Online|first=FOCUS|work=FOCUS Online|access-date=2018-07-22|language=de}}</ref>
According to German [[Federal Agency for Civic Education]], the salafist movement in Germany is centered in the [[Frankfurt Rhine-Main|Frankfurt Rhine-Main metropolitan area]], [[North Rhine-Westphalia]] and Berlin. In these areas mosques and charismatic imams are the driving factors behind recruitment to the salafist movement.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.bpb.de/politik/extremismus/islamismus/268726/orte-der-islamistischen-radikalisierung|title=Orte der islamistischen Radikalisierung {{!}} bpb|last=Jaschke|first=Hans-Gerd|work=bpb.de|access-date=2018-12-01|language=de}}</ref>
In 2016, the interior minstry of [[North Rhine-Westphalia]] reported that the number of mosques with a salafist influence had risen from 30 to 55, which indicated both an actual increase and improved reporting.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://rp-online.de/nrw/panorama/nrw-salafisten-agitieren-in-55-moscheen_aid-18340503|title=Verfassungsschutz: Salafisten agitieren in NRW in 55 Moscheen|last=ONLINE|first=RP|work=RP ONLINE|access-date=2018-11-18|language=de}}</ref>
In February 2017, salafist mosque organisation ''Berliner Fussilet-Moscheeverein'' was banned by authoritiess. Anas Amri, the perpetrator of the [[2016 Berlin truck attack]] was among its visitors. In March 2017 the community organisation ''Deutschsprachige Islamkreis Hildesheim'' was banned as Muslims were being prepared for travelling to the conflict zone in Syria to fight for the Islamic State. These examples show that salafist mosques not only concern themselves with religious matters, but also serious crime and terrorist activities are prepared.<ref name=":0" />
===Islamist scene in Germany=== Turkish and Kurdish Islamist groups are also active in Germany, and Turkish and Kurdish Islamists have co-operated in Germany as in the case of the Sauerland terror cell.<ref name="ReferenceA">*German Jihad: On the Internationalisation of Islamist Terrorism by Guido Steinberg. Columbia University Press, 2013</ref> Political scientist Guido Steinberg stated that many top leaders of Islamist organizations in Turkey fled to Germany in the 2000s, and that the Turkish (Kurdish) Hizbullah has also "left an imprint on Turkish Kurds in Germany."<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Also many Kurds from Iraq (there are about 50,000 to 80,000 Iraqi Kurds in Germany) financially supported Kurdish-Islamist groups like Ansar al Islam.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Many Islamists in Germany are ethnic Kurds (Iraqi and Turkish Kurds) or Turks. Before 2006, the German Islamist scene was dominated by Iraqi Kurds and Palestinians, but since 2006 Kurds and Turks from Turkey are dominant.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
In 2016, the German security service estimated that about 24 000 Muslims were part of Islamists movements in Germany, of which 10 000 belonged to the Salafist scene.<ref name=":0" />
In 2016, 90 mosques were monitored by the [[Federal Office for the Protection of the Constitution]] for their [[Islamism|islamist ideology]]. These were mostly Arabic-language "backyard mosques" where self-appointed imams exhorted their followers to wage jihad.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sueddeutsche.de/politik/islamismus-verdacht-verfassungsschutz-beobachtet-etwa-moscheen-in-deutschland-1.2976423|title=Verfassungsschutz beobachtet etwa 90 Moscheen in Deutschland|date=2016|work=sueddeutsche.de|access-date=2018-11-18|language=de|issn=0174-4917}}</ref>
Since the start of 2017 until April 2018, 80 islamist extremists without German citizenship were deported to their home countries.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.welt.de/politik/deutschland/article176069850/Justiz-Top-Gefaehrder-aus-Hessen-abgeschoben.html|title=Justiz: Top-Gefährder aus Hessen abgeschoben|last=Flade|first=Florian|date=2018-05-04|work=DIE WELT|access-date=2018-05-05}}</ref>
In March 2018, there were 760 islamists in Germany classified as dangerous by [[Federal Criminal Police Office (Germany)|police authorities]], of which more than half were on German territory and 153 of the latter were in prison.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dw.com/de/bundeskriminalamt-z%C3%A4hlt-760-islamistische-gef%C3%A4hrder/a-43203952|title=Bundeskriminalamt zählt 760 islamistische Gefährder {{!}} DW {{!}} 31.03.2018|last=(www.dw.com)|first=Deutsche Welle|website=DW.COM|language=de|access-date=2018-05-10}}</ref>
===Banning of IHH Germany=== In July 2010, Germany outlawed the [[Internationale Humanitäre Hilfsorganisation e.V.]] (IHH Germany), saying it had used donations to support [[Hamas]], which is considered by the European Union and Germany to be a terrorist organization,<ref name="Hilfsorganisation">{{cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3918670,00.html|title=Germany bans group accused of Hamas links|author=|date=7 December 2010|website=ynetnews.com|accessdate=3 April 2018}}</ref><ref name="IHH"/> while presenting their activities to donors as humanitarian help. German Interior Minister [[Thomas de Maiziere]] said, "[[Donations]] to so-called social welfare groups belonging to Hamas, such as the millions given by IHH, actually support the terror organization Hamas as a whole."<ref name="Hilfsorganisation"/><ref name="IHH">{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/germany-outlaws-ihh-over-claimed-hamas-links-1.301483|title=Germany Outlaws Charity Over Alleged Hamas Links|first=|last=DPA|date=12 July 2010|publisher=|accessdate=3 April 2018|via=Haaretz}}</ref> IHH e.V. was believed by the German Authorities to have collected money in mosques and to have sent $8.3 million to organizations related to Hamas.<ref name="Zaman">{{Cite web|title=Germany IHH e.V. ban shameful, illegal, says group leader|work=Today's Zaman|date=14 July 2010|url=http://www.todayszaman.com/tz-web/detaylar.do?load=detay&link=215989}}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
== Religiosity of young Muslims == Studies show that while not all Muslims are religious, Muslim youths are markedly more religious than non-Muslim youths. A study comparing Turkish Muslim youths living in Germany and German youth found that the former were more likely to attend religious services regularly (35% versus 14%).<ref name="Gesemann2">Frank Gesemann. "Die Integration junger Muslime in Deutschland. Interkultureller Dialog - Islam und Gesellschaft Nr. 5 (year of 2006). Friedrich Ebert Stiftung", on p. 9 - the document is written in German</ref>
41% of young Turkish Muslim boys and 52% of the girls said they prayed "sometimes or regularly"; 64% of boys and 74% of girls said they wanted to teach their children religion.<ref name="Gesemann2"/>
According to a 2012 poll, 25% of the [[Turks in Germany]] believe atheists are inferior human beings.<ref>Liljeberg Research International: [https://d171.keyingress.de/multimedia/document/228.pdf ''Deutsch-Türkische Lebens und Wertewelten 2012''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121011112234/https://d171.keyingress.de/multimedia/document/228.pdf |date=11 October 2012 }}, July/August 2012, p. 68</ref><ref>[[Die Welt]]: [https://www.welt.de/politik/deutschland/article108659406/Tuerkische-Migranten-hoffen-auf-muslimische-Mehrheit.html ''Türkische Migranten hoffen auf muslimische Mehrheit''], 17 August 2012, retrieved 23 August 2012</ref>

page.title: List of former mosques in Spain

revision.comment: Adding [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "Spanish mosque" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|Spanish mosque}} [[File:Mezquita de Córdoba desde el aire (Córdoba, España).jpg|thumb|right|300px|[[Mosque–Cathedral of Córdoba]], one of the best preserved old mosques in Spain.]] This is a '''list of former mosques in Spain'''. It lists former [[Muslim]] [[mosques]] ([[Arabic]]: Masjid, [[Spanish language|Spanish]]: Mezquita) and [[Islamic]] places of worship in [[Spain]]. It lists some but by no means all of the old mosques of Spain. For open, functioning mosques please see [[list of mosques in Spain]].
The term '''former mosque''' in this list includes any [[Muslim]] [[mosque]] (building) or site used for Islamic Prayer ([[Salah]]) in [[Spain]] but is not so any longer.
Most of the former mosques in Spain were built and used as Muslim places of worship during the [[Al-Andalus]] (Muslim Spain) period from 711 AD to 1492 AD when various Muslim [[Moors|Moorish]] kingdoms ruled large parts of the [[Iberian Peninsula]]. Most of these former mosques and religious buildings were either demolished or converted into churches after the Christian reconquest of the Iberian Peninsula (the [[Reconquista]]).<ref name="a1">{{cite web |title=5 Most Impressive Historic Mosques in Spain |url=http://historylists.org/architecture/5-most-impressive-historic-mosques-in-spain.html |website=historylists.org |accessdate=27 September 2018}}</ref>
This list does not include the [[List of former mosques in Portugal|former mosques of Portugal]] that were built during [[Al-Andalus|Al-andalus]] era.
==History== [[Mosques]] were an integral part of Spanish social, political and cultural spheres during the Muslim rule of Spain (711 - 1492 AD). Subsequently they played an important role in Spanish history for over eight centuries. However, with the exception of the [[Great Mosque of Cordoba]], there is very little documentation or published information available in English language about these old historical mosques of Spain.
There are only estimates about the number of former Spanish mosques. However there seem to have existed several hundreds and possibly even thousands of mosques in Spain. According to one estimate, there were 3,000 mosques, bath and palaces in [[Córdoba, Spain|Cordoba]] city alone. This was during the 10th century, when Cordoba was one of the largest cities in the world and had over 250,0000 buildings spread across a area of twenty four miles long and six miles wide. Today these old mosques in Cordoba are lost without a trace with the exception of the [[Great Mosque of Cordoba]] and few other ruins and remains like ''Minaret of San Juan''.<ref name="b1">{{cite web |title=The Great Mosque of Cordoba: Geometric Analysis |url=http://islamic-arts.org/2011/the-great-mosque-of-cordoba-geometric-analysis/ |website=islamic-arts.org |accessdate=18 October 2018}}</ref>
At onetime there were 137 mosques in the Medina of [[Granada|Grenada]] when it was the capital city of the [[Emirate of Granada]] (1230-1492).<ref name="b2">{{cite web |title=Minaret of San Juan De Los Reyes and Mosque of The Conversos |url=http://legadonazari.blogspot.com/2014/06/alminar-de-san-juan-de-los-reyes-y.html |website=legadonazari.blogspot.com |accessdate=18 October 2018}}</ref> During this period the Medina (city) of Granada was one of the largest cities in Europe and accepted large number of Muslim refugees expelled from the Christian controlled areas. This doubled its size, and by 1450 made it the largest city in Europe in terms of population.<ref>[http://www.muslimheritage.com/uploads/Granada.pdf Granada- The Last Refuge of Muslims in Spain] by Salah Zaimeche</ref>
Proliferation of mosques was not limited to the large cities. Even small cities and towns had multiple mosques built for the easy and quick access of the faithful to perform their daily five times Islamic prayers ([[Salah]]) in congregation. There were 18 mosques in [[Jerez, Spain|Jerez]] city, of which only the mosque within the fortress of [[Alcazar of Jerez de la Frontera]] survives today.<ref name="a1"></ref> There were 16 mosques in [[Vélez-Málaga]] (then known as Ballis Medina) during the Nazari [[Emirate of Granada|Granada Emirate]] period.<ref name="b3">{{cite web |title=Mosque of Velez Malaga |url=http://legadonazari.blogspot.com/2013/07/mezquita-de-velez-malaga.html |website=legadonazari.blogspot.com |accessdate=18 October 2018}}</ref> [[Ronda, Spain|Ronda]] a smaller town had 7 or 8 mosques of which none exist today except a minaret tower of a medium-size mosque.<ref name=":1"></ref> About 5 former mosques still exists in [[Toledo, Spain|Toledo]] with the original structures at-least partially preserved as shown in the list below.
==List of former mosques in Spain (with original buildings & ruins)== This table lists former mosques in Spain with ''identified'' original buildings or ruins of the former mosque still existing on the premises.
''Note'': ''Mesquita'' means mosque in the [[Spanish language|Spanish]] language. {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders sortable" style="text-align:left;" |- !Current Name !Mosque Name ! class="unsortable" |Images !City !Province !Year Opened !Year Closed ! class="unsortable" |Notes ! class="unsortable" |Ref. |- |[[Mosque–Cathedral of Córdoba]] |Great Mosque of Córdoba (Qurṭuba), Aljama Mosque |[[File:Mezquita de Córdoba desde el aire (Córdoba, España).jpg|100px]][[File:Mosque Cordoba.jpg|100px]] |[[Córdoba, Spain|Córdoba]] |[[Andalusia]] |early 8th century |1236 |After [[Muslim conquest of Spain]] (710~), the site of former main [[Visigoths|Visigothic]] church of Cordoba was divided and shared between Muslims and Christians for seven decades. Later [[Abd al-Rahman I]] purchased Christian part and built the great mosque in 785.<ref name="L. M">{{citation |author=L. M. |title=La basílica de San Vicente Mártir, la primacía de lo cristiano |publisher=[[ABC (newspaper)|ABC]] |url=http://sevilla.abc.es/cordoba/20140227/sevi-basilica-vicente-martir-primacia-201402262131.html |date=February 27, 2014}}</ref> Major extensions were added in 9th and 10th centuries, until final extention by in 10th century under [[Almanzor]]. After Christians captured Cordoba in 1236, King Ferdinand III of [[Crown of Castile|Castile]] converted the mosque into a cathedral. Later, a cathedral was built at the center of the old mosque, configuring the current Mosque-Cathedral of Cordoba. It was the second largest mosque in the world after Mecca Great mosque from the around 9th century, until [[Sultan Ahmed Mosque]], [[Istanbul]] was built in 1588. It had a surface area of {{convert|23,400|m2|ha|lk=in}} and accommodated an estimated 32,000 to 40,000 worshipers. Current mosque structure date from 784 to 987.<ref name="a1"></ref> |<ref name="a1"></ref><ref name="a2">{{cite web |title=Magnificent Mosques of Spain |url=https://www.halaltrip.com/other/blog/mosques-of-spain/ |website=halaltrip.com |accessdate=27 September 2018}}</ref> |- |[[Mosque of Cristo de la Luz]] |Mezquita Bab-al-Mardum |[[File:Mezquita Cristo de la Luz de Toledo.jpg|100px]] |[[Toledo, Spain|Toledo]] |[[Castilla–La Mancha]] |999 |1186 |Converted into a church. One of the best preserved Moorish mosques in Spain.<ref name="a1"></ref> |<ref name="a1"></ref><ref name="a2"></ref> |- |[[Giralda]] |Great Mosque of Seville |[[File:Sevilla Cathedral - Giralda.jpg|100px]] |[[Seville]] |[[Andalusia]] | |1248 |Only minaret remains. Mosque comparable in size to [[Mosque-Cathedral of Cordoba|Great mosque of Cordoba]], destroyed by earthquake in 1365. Minaret used as a church bell tower was built higher in 16th century. |<ref name="a1"></ref> |- |Mezquita de Almonaster la Real | |[[File:Almonaster la real vue d'ensemble.jpg|100px]] |[[Almonaster la Real]] |[[Andalusia]] |10th century | | Built on site of 5th century Visigoth basilica. Converted into a Church after Reconquista. National Monument since 1931. |<ref name="a1"></ref><ref name="a2"></ref> |- |Mezquita del Alcázar de Jerez la Frontera | |[[File:Mezquita del Alcázar de Jerez (33047903241).jpg|100px]] |[[Jerez de la Frontera]] (Jerez) |[[Andalusia]] |11th century |mid 13th century | Located within former Moorish fortress of [[Alcazar of Jerez de la Frontera]]. Only surviving mosque building of 18 former mosques in the [[Jerez]] city. Converted into church after Reconquista. |<ref name="a1"></ref><ref name="a2"></ref> |- |[[Mosque of las Tornerías]] |Al-Mustimim |[[File:Visita a las obras de rehabilitación de la Mezquita de Tornerías (43539278162).jpg|100px]] |[[Toledo, Spain|Toledo]] |[[Castilla–La Mancha]] |1060<ref name="a3">{{cite web |title=Las Tornerías |url=https://archnet.org/sites/3742 |website=archnet.org |accessdate=27 September 2018}}</ref> | |Unusual two-storied mosque. Was built in a busy commercial neighborhood (Arrabal de Francos). Used as a church until 1498-1505, and other uses since. Restoration and preservation done recently. |<ref name="a2"></ref><ref name="a3"></ref><ref name="a4">{{cite web |title=Fusion of Roman, Visigoth and Muslim culture |url=http://www.turismocastillalamancha.es/patrimonio/mezquita-de-las-tornerias-14764/descripcion/ |website=turismocastillalamancha.es |accessdate=27 September 2018}}</ref> |- |Mezquita de Tórtoles | |[[File:Mezquita de Tórtoles, Tarazona, Zaragoza, España, 2017-05-23, DD 66.jpg|frameless|100x100px]] |[[Tarazona]] |[[Aragon]] | |15th century |Mosque remains almost not altered in the later centuries. Current building was built in 2 stages, one early 15th century, other late 15th century. It is attached to the remains of the old fortified tower of town castle. Converted into a church in 1526. |<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.patrimonioculturaldearagon.es/bienes-culturales/mezquita-de-tortoles-tarazona|title=Mosque of Tórtoles (Tarazona, ZARAGOZA)|last=|first=|date=|website=patrimonioculturaldearagon.es|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=28 September 2018}}</ref> |- |Aljama Mosque of [[Medina Azahara]] |Aljama Masjid of Madinat al-Zahra |[[File:Mezquita de Medina Azahara.jpg|frameless|100x100px]] |[[Córdoba, Spain|Córdoba]] |[[Andalusia]] |940 |1010 |A mosque in [[Madinat Al-Zahra|Madinat al-Zahra]], a vast, fortified [[Moors|Moorish]] palace-city built by [[Abd ar-Rahman III|Abd-ar-Rahman III]] (912–961). The marbled, jeweled complex was plundered & destroyed first by Muslims, then by Christians when civil war ended [[Caliphate of Córdoba]]. A UNESCO World Heritage site since 2018. |<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.andalucia.com/magazine/english/ed4/madinat.htm|title=Cordoba City - Madinat al-Zahra|last=|first=|date=|website=andalucia.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=28 September 2018}}</ref> |- |[[San Sebastián, Toledo|San Sebastián de Toledo]] |Al-Dabbagin Masjid |[[File:Toledo 2015 10 26 2803 (26732620315) (cropped) iglesia de San Sebastián.jpg|frameless|100x100px]] |[[Toledo, Spain|Toledo]] |[[Castilla–La Mancha]] | |1085~ |Converted into a church after 1085 Christian conquest of area. Renovated several times but original interior structure remains. Building now used as a concert & exhibition hall. Bell tower built in 15th century shows characteristics of former minaret. Ruins of Arab Baths of Tenerías remain lower below on slope.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://www.arteguias.com/mezquita/sansebastiantoledo.htm|title=Church (old mosque) of San Sebastián de Toledo|last=|first=|date=|website=arteguias.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=28 September 2018}}</ref> A short reference to mosque exist by Ibn Baskuwal (1101-83) reported by Fath ibn Ibrahim. <ref name=":3">The existence of the Al-Dabbagin mosque is attested by a short reference by Ibn Baskuwal (1101-83) reported by Fath ibn Ibrahim. see: <nowiki>''</nowiki>Actas de las i jornadas de Cultura Islámica, Toledo<nowiki>''</nowiki>, Instituto Occidental de Cultura Islámica (ed.) 1987, p. 158</ref> |<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3" /> |- |Small Royal mosque inside [[Aljafería|Aljafería Palace]] | |[[File:La Aljafería 14092014 114703 05575.jpg|frameless|100x100px]] |[[Zaragoza]] |[[Aragon]] |10th century | |Located inside the great fortified palace. A small octagonal mosque, designed as a private oratory for the king and his family. Mosque architecture inspired by Córdoba mosque. Aljafería is a UNESCO World Heritage site since 1986.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.discoverislamicart.org/database_item.php?id=monument;isl;es;mon01;4;en|title=Aljafería Palace (Islamic part) in Discover Islamic Art|last=|first=|date=|website=discoverislamicart.org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=28 September 2018}}</ref> |<ref name=":0" /> |- |[[Mezquita-Iglesia de El Salvador, Toledo]] | |[[File:Iglesia del Salvador. Toledo.jpg|frameless|133x133px]] |[[Toledo, Spain|Toledo]] |[[Castilla–La Mancha]] |9th century |1085 |Mosque built on former Visigoth or Roman substrate. Now a rebuilt church but excavations revealed 9th century structures & elements of mosque - horseshoe arch arcade, primitive stone minaret, flooring, courtyard with cistern.<ref name=":16">{{Cite web|url=http://www.turismocastillalamancha.es/patrimonio/iglesia-de-el-salvador-de-toledo-12864/descripcion/|title=Iglesia de El Salvador de Toledo|last=|first=|date=|website=turismocastillalamancha.es|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=28 September 2018}}</ref><ref name=":17">{{Cite web|url=http://www.toledomonumental.com/savador.html|title=Church of the Savior|last=|first=|date=|website=toledomonumental.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=28 September 2018}}</ref> |<ref name=":16" /> <ref name=":17" /> |- |Alminar de Árchez, Alminar Mudéjar (Mudejar Minaret of Árchez) |Masyid al-Ta`ibin, Mezquita de los Conversos<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:San_Juan_de_los_Reyes_(Granada)._Alminar.jpg|title=San Juan de los Reyes (Granada) Alminar|last=|first=|date=|website=wikipedia.org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=28 September 2018}}</ref> (Mosque of convert) |[[File:Alminar 1.jpg|frameless|133x133px]] |[[Árchez]] |[[Andalusia]] | |14th century |Only 15 meter tall [[minaret]] remains, used as bellfry of Árchez church built on mosque location. Minaret is a [[Almohad architecture|Almohade architecture]] monument and only remaining jewel of Nazarí period.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=http://www.malaga.es/en/turismo/patrimonio/lis_cd-5075/cnl-50/alminar-mudejar-archez|title=Mudejar Minaret|last=|first=|date=|website=malaga.es|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=29 September 2018}}</ref> |<ref name=":4" /> |- |San Sebastian Minaret (Alminar De San Sebastian) | |[[File:Ronda Minaret-Kirchturm2004.jpg|frameless|150x150px]] |[[Ronda]] |[[Andalusia]] | |1485 |Only minaret of the medium-size mosque in Plaza Abul Beka neighborhood remains. Minaret was expanded and used as a bell tower. The mosque was converted to a church but destroyed in 1600s during [[Rebellion of the Alpujarras (1568–71)|Morisco Revolts]]. Ronda was a Muslim city for 700 years. The city had 7 or 8 mosques, none survive today.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.rondatoday.com/san-sebastian-minaret-alminar-de-san-sebastian/|title=San Sebastian Minaret|last=|first=|date=|website=rondatoday.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=28 September 2018}}</ref> |<ref name=":1" /> |- |Alminar de San Juan (Minaret of San Juan) | |[[File:Cordoue (3873429397).jpg|frameless|100x100px]] |[[Córdoba, Spain|Córdoba]] |[[Andalusia]] |930 | |Only minaret remains of mosque built in 930 during 1st Spanish Umayyad caliph 'Abd al-Rahman III. Caliphate era minaret survives. Church is a [[Mudéjar]] style masterpiece, built in 1245-47 on prior structures of a mosque and Visigoth building.<ref name=":20">{{Cite web|url=http://www.discoverislamicart.org/database_item.php?id=monument;ISL;es;Mon01;29;en|title=Church of Santiago del Arrabal|last=|first=|date=|website=discoverislamicart.org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=28 September 2018}}</ref> |<ref name=":20" /> |- |Church of Nuestra Señora de la Encarnación (Benaque, Macharaviaya) | |[[File:Benaque.jpg|frameless|100x100px]] |[[Macharaviaya]] | | | |One of few preserved mosques with original minaret and solid block building built of brick & masonry. Interior single rectangular prayer hall now a church nave. Drilling Mecca facing wall in 2003 showed original mosque construction and 19th century work. [[Reconquista|Reconquesta]] era document says "...While it was the visitation and reformation of the houses in the alcayua (or alamiya) in Benaque, the inhabitants used mosque as a parish church, where they had images and heard Mass..." .<ref name=":22">{{Cite web|url=https://andaluciarustica.com/en/macharaviaya-parish-church-of-nuestra-senora-de-la-encarnacion-in-benaque.htm|title=Parish Church of Nuestra Señora de la Encarnación Benaque|last=|first=|date=|website=andaluciarustica.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=30 September 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.viajerosencortomalaga.com/066005002c04t05.html|title=Church of Our Lady of the Incarnation. ==List of former mosques in Spain (with original buildings destroyed)== This table lists former mosques in Spain with ''no known'' surviving mosque buildings. The original mosques were completely destroyed by people, war or by natural causes like earthquakes. Other structures were built on the site destroying or covering traces of the mosque. The ruins and stone materials of the mosque were often reused to build the new structures. However these sites may still contain undiscovered original structures within the current buildings or un-excavated ruins on the premises.

revision.text:
The '''luang pho phet''' ({{lang-th|หลวงพ่อเพชร}}) is a type of image of the [[Gautama Buddha|Buddha]] found in [[Thailand]]. A luang pho phet depicts the Buddha in the ''Diamond [[Lotus Position]].''
==Notable luang pho phet images== [[File:Luang Pho Phet (Wat Tha Thanon).jpg|thumb|Luang pho phet at Wat Tha Thanon]] Notable luang pho phet Buddha images include the luang pho phet of [[Uttaradit]] (in Wat Tha Thanon), the luang pho phet of [[Phichit]] (in Wat Tha Luang), and the luang pho phet of [[Nakhon Thai Subdistrict|Nakhon Thai]] (in Wat Na Phra That). The luang pho phet in Uttaradit is believed to have been constructed between 800 and 900 years ago.<ref name="Chimburi.com">[http://www.chimburi.com/thai485.htm Wat Tha Thanon temple on Chimburi.com]</ref>
==luang pho phet in prayer==
An English translation of a common Pali chant to be said before a luang pho phet image is as follows:<ref name="Wat Pradhātu">See, e.g., [http://vipassanasangha.free.fr/ChantingBook.pdf Chanting Book of Wat Pradhātu Srī Chomtong Voravihāra]</ref> :By body, by speech, and by mind, I will always revere the image named luang pho phet, :the Buddha statue, working wonders of psychic power. May I be blessed forevermore.
The text of the chant in Pali is as follows: :Kāyena vācāya va cetassa vā vajiraü nāma pañimaü iddhi-pāñihāriyakaraü buddha-rūpaü ahaü vandāmi sabbaso; sadā sotthī bhavantu me.

{{Infobox Book | name = Magic: History, Theory and Practice | title_orig = Magie: Geschichte, Theorie, Praxis | translator = | image = | image_caption = | author = Dr. Ernst Schertel | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = Germany | language = [[German language|German]] | subject = [[Magic (paranormal)|Magic]] | publisher = Anthropos-Verlag | pub_date = 1923 | english_pub_date = 2009 | pages = 154 | isbn = }} '''''Magic: History, Theory and Practice''''' is a [[Mysticism|mysticism book]] by [[Ernst Schertel]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Magic: History, Theory, Practice|last=Schertel|first=Ernst|publisher=Catalog of the Universal Mind|year=2009|isbn=978-0578024578|location=Boise, Idaho|pages=}}</ref> Originally published in Germany in 1923, ''Magic: History / Theory / Practice'' (in its original German edition), was a hardcover book consisting of 154 pages.
Schertel identifies heavily with the "demonic" in ''Magic'', espousing the belief that "communion with the demon" is the most important aspect of magical/religious practice. In addition to this, Schertel also identified the following elements of magic:
# Ecstasy. The performer must enter an altered mind state of “ecstasy”, “possession” or “somnambulism”, and it is usually achieved by dancing, chanting, hypnosis, intoxication, and even sacrifices.<ref name=":0" /> He wrote in the book, “Originally, prophecy meant just “speaking while being delighted with god,” and this already shows that for this kind of magic the amalgamation with the demon, that is to say an ecstasy (trance) was seen as a precondition as much as with every other kind of magic.”Some modern authors believe that it is equivalent to the [[Alpha wave|alpha]] state of mind.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Code of the Extraordinary Mind: 10 Unconventional Laws to Redefine Your Life and Succeed On Your Own Terms|last=Lakhiani|first=Vishen|publisher=Rodale Books|year=10 May 2016|isbn=978-1623367084|location=New York|pages=}}</ref> # Imagination. It is the way through which the performer bring the desired changes into reality. Schertel wrote, “The man with the greatest force of imagination is commanding of the world and creates realities according to his will, instead of being the slave of an unsubstantial, bodiless empiricism.”<ref name=":0" /> He thinks that magic is autogenic exertion of power on the basis of imagination, and reality is nothing more than the becoming-an-image of our deepest essential powers, and thus the observation of truth is not a process of “depiction” but of “construction”. #Body-feeling. The performer is required to develop a kind of “body feeling” through “body exercises”. However, here Schertel is not referring to common muscle-building or physical training nowadays. The two forms of exercises that he recommends are “senual” and “articular”. “The sensual practices stand for a passive listening-into the body and are therefore preferably happening out of a state of relaxation, the articular practices on the other hand represent a violent, almost mechanical pushing and bending of individual joints or of the whole body... These practices are supported by certain breathing methods.”<ref name=":0" /> He also points out that to increase body feeling, many magicians often perform with loose clothes or even naked.
In 2003 it was revealed that Schertel had sent a dedicated copy of the book to [[Adolf Hitler]]. Hitler read the book and marked several passages.<ref>Ryback, Timothy. [https://www.theatlantic.com/doc/200305/ryback ''Hitler's Forgotten Library'']. ''[[The Atlantic]]'', May 2003.</ref> A total of sixty-six annotations were made by Hitler in his copy. Eventually the Hitler copy was obtained from the [[John Hay Library]] at [[Brown University]] and the book was translated into English with his annotations added.
Some of the passages marked by Hitler include: * “False images are necessary for the recognition of truth.” * “He who does not have the demonic seed within himself will never give birth to a magical world.” * “Satan is the beginning…”<ref>Kelley, JH. [http://www.prlog.org/10238075-new-translation-of-german-book-links-hitler-to-satanism.html "New Translation of German Book Links Hitler to Satanism"] (press release). PRLog, May 17, 2009. Accessed 28 June 2009.</ref>

{{Orphan|date=November 2013}} The '''Max Stern Art Restitution Project''' was initiated as an effort to locate artworks lost by Dr. [[Max Stern (gallery owner)|Max Stern]] during [[World War II]].
==Background information== Max Stern was a world-renowned art collector and gallery owner who died in 1987. During World War II, Stern was forced to flee the [[Nazi regime]] and relocate to [[Canada]]. While escaping, he lost his private collection of valued artworks through forced sale and confiscation. After the war, Stern sought [[restitution]] of these works. Unfortunately, he had limited success and only managed to recover several pieces. The majority of his property was never returned.
==The project== The Max Stern Art Restitution Project was established by the executors and university beneficiaries of the Max Stern Estate. An official announcement outlining the initiation of the project and its goals was made on April 28, 2005. This announcement occurred in [[Quebec]], and was given by Dr. Clarence Epstein of [[Concordia University]].<ref name="Concordia Article">{{cite web|last=Lecavalier|first=Catherine|title=Concordia Commits to Seeking Restitution of Max Stern's Art Holdings Lost During the Nazi Regime|url=https://www.concordia.ca/content/dam/concordia/docs/max-stern/Concordia-Commits-to-Seeking-Restitution.pdf|publisher=Concordia University|accessdate=22 November 2013}}</ref> The project is seeking the [[restitution]] of art pieces originally owned by the late Max Stern. These pieces were either confiscated by the [[Nazi Party]], or sold under duress in the 1930s.<ref name="Concordia Article" /> While project members realize that locating missing artwork is a great challenge, they decided that the moral and financial imperatives surrounding the cause make it worth the effort.
[[Concordia University]] has been a leader in the restitution movement, and is working closely with the Art Loss Register in London, the Commission of Looted Art in Europe, and the New York State Holocaust Claims Processing Office. Since Concordia launched its efforts, 250 artworks previously owned by Stern have been identified. These include pieces by [[Jan Brueghel the Younger|Brueghel]], [[Hieronymus Bosch|Bosch]], [[Ludovico Carracci|Carracci]] and [[Franz Xaver Winterhalter|Winterhalter]]. Five works have been located in the [[United States]], [[England]], the [[Netherlands]] or [[Germany]].<ref name="Concordia Article" /> As artworks are reclaimed and possession is acquired, estate executors plan to loan the pieces to museums and galleries. This decision was made based on Max Stern's ideals, as he was always encouraging art education and passion in [[Canada]] and around the world. Executors and beneficiaries have expressed their wish to avoid using the courts, and instead wish to utilize moral persuasion in convincing institutions and individuals to return works to the appropriate beneficiaries.<ref name="Concordia Article" />
The Max Stern Art Restitution Project was not initiated only to find missing works. Rather, it was also created as an incentive to motivate governments, museums, collectors and the art trade towards resolving injustices caused by Nazi cultural policies. In order to commence this movement, the restitution project chose to spearhead the ''Auktion 392 ''exhibit.
==''Auktion 392''== Launched in fall of 2006, ''Auktion 392 ''is a traveling exhibit surrounding the forced sale of Stern paintings in the Lempertz auction house during 1937. This exhibit was created by FOFA gallery coordinator Lynn Beavis and designer Andrew Elvish. It also accompanies the seminal research of Professor Catherine MacKenzie and MA students from Concordia's Department of Art History.<ref name="Auktion Press Release">{{cite web|last=Uri|first=Ben|title=AUKTION 392 Reclaiming the Galerie Stern, Düsseldorf|url=https://www.concordia.ca/content/dam/concordia/docs/max-stern/benUri_press.pdf|publisher=London Jewish Museum of Art|accessdate=22 November 2013}}</ref> The exhibition outlines the unique story of Max Stern, and the legal issues of art restitution stemming from [[anti-Semitic]] policies during [[World War II]]. There is historical meaning behind the name of this exhibit. In 1935, after Stern had his art trading license withdrawn, he was forced to sell his artworks under extreme duress. The sale was arranged by Lempertz auctioneers in [[Cologne]], and the auction was titled Auktion 392.<ref name="Auktion book">{{cite book|last=MacKenzie|first=Catherine|title=Auktion 392: Reclaiming the Galerie Stern, Dusseldorf|year=2006|publisher=Concordia University|location=Montreal}}</ref> This exhibit is extremely valuable to the Max Stern Art Restitution Project, as it raises public awareness of art restitution matters.
==Issues in restitution== Recovering the missing artwork has been no simple task. There have been several instances where pieces have been located, but a lack of cooperation keeps the works from being acquired. Take, for example, the issue surrounding two artworks originally sold under duress by Stern. The two paintings, ''Market Scene in the Piazza Navona ''and ''Market Scene in the Piazza del Quirinale'', were created by a [[Netherlands|Dutch]] [[Baroque painter]] named Mathijs Naiveu. These paintings were discovered while being auctioned in the Van Ham auction house, which is located in [[Cologne]].<ref name="Second Website Concordia">{{cite web|last=Churchmuch|first=Tanya|title=German auction house to proceed with sale of Nazi- tainted art despite objections|url=https://www.concordia.ca/content/dam/concordia/docs/max-stern/german-auction-house-to-proceed.pdf|publisher=Concordia University|accessdate=23 November 2013}}</ref> On November 8, 2006, it was requested that the artworks be removed from the upcoming auction. The Stern Estate had been pursuing the paintings for several years, ever since the possessor tried to sell them in [[Amsterdam]]. Unfortunately, the German possessor refused to acknowledge the forced sale that took place during the [[Nazi era]]. Consequently, the Van Ham sale was scheduled to proceed despite the tainted history.<ref name="Second Website Concordia"/>
In order to be reclaimed, each discovered artwork has to run through a legal process which varies depending on its located country. Some pieces present extreme challenges, like the [[Nicolas Neufchatel|Neufchatel]] portrait of Jan van Eversdijck. Upon discovery, this portrait was deemed part of the patrimony of the Illes Beleares province in [[Spain]]. This patrimony made difficult for project members to claim their right of ownership. Fortunately, the painting has since been restituted and is one of the 11 paintings reclaimed by the Max Stern Art Restitution Project. This particular portrait was easy to locate because it was posted on a museum website up until 2006.<ref name="Auktion book" /> Other paintings are much more difficult to find. This difficulty stems from the fact that a large number of Stern's stock was not illustrated, and few of the given titles were likely to have remained over the years. Unfortunately, art galleries and auction houses are not required to provide background information on works of art in their possession. Dealers will often be in possession of the full story behind a specific painting, but choose to suppress this information for business reasons.<ref name="Auktion book" />
Research conducted has learned that upwards of forty paintings originally owned by Stern have since been re-offered on the market in the last two decades, usually through major auction houses in [[Germany]]. The Stern Estate continues to plead with [[Germany|German]] auction houses, hoping to make them recognize the validity of the estate's ownership regarding looted artworks.<ref name="Third article">{{cite web|last=Downey|first=Fiona|title=German Auction House refuses to withdraw painting claimed by Stern Estate|url=https://www.concordia.ca/content/dam/concordia/docs/max-stern/german-auction-house.pdf|publisher=Concordia University|accessdate=23 November 2013}}</ref>
==Works recovered by the project== While facing a lot of difficulty in their endeavor to locate the missing Stern paintings, the Max Stern Art Restitution Project has also been presented with countless victories. To date, they have managed to recover the following works: *''Scandinavian Landscape ''by Andreas Achanbach – Restituted October 2013 *''Virgin and Child ''by [[Master of Flemalle]] – Restituted March 2013 *''The Masters of the Goldsmith Guild in Amsterdam in 1701'' by Juriaen Pool II – Restituted October 2011 *''Allegory of Earth and Water ''by [[Jan Brueghel the Younger]] – Restituted November 2010 *''St. Jerome ''by [[Lodovico Carracci]] – Restituted May 2009 *''Portrait of a Musician Playing a Bagpipe, 1632 ''by Northern Netherlandish School – Restituted April 2009 *''Flight into Egypt ''by Circle of Jan Wellens de Cock – Restituted December 2008 *''Girl from the Sabine Mountains'' by [[Franz Xaver Winterhalter]] – Restituted January 2008 *''Extensive Landscape with Travelers on a Track Near a Walled Town with a Castle and a Church, a Village Beyond ''by [[Jan de Vos I]] – Restituted December 2007 *''Portrait of Jan van Eversdyck ''by [[Nicolas Neufchatel]] – Restituted February 2007 *''Aimée, A Young Egyptian ''by Emile C.H. Vernet-Lecomte – Restituted October 2006 <gallery> De overlieden van het Amsterdamse goud- en zilversmidsgilde door Juriaen Pool (1701).PNG|''The Masters of the Goldsmith Guild in Amsterdam in 1701'' Girl from the Sabine Mountains.jpg|''Girl from the Sabine Mountains'' </gallery>

{{about|images formed with tiny letters|photography using microscopes|Micrograph|miniaturized photographs|Microphotograph}} {{Citation style|date=January 2010}}
'''Micrography''' (from [[Greek language|Greek]], literally small-writing – "Μικρογραφία"), also called '''microcalligraphy''', is a [[Jew]]ish form of [[calligram]]s developed in the 9th century, with parallels in Christianity and Islam,<ref>[http://expositions.bnf.fr/parole/grand/134.htm Torah, Bible, Coran] (French)</ref> utilizing minute [[Hebrew alphabet|Hebrew letters]] to form representational, geometric and abstract designs. Colored micrography is especially distinctive because these rare artworks are customarily rendered in black and white.
== Description == The artwork is created from text that forms an image when viewed at a distance, creating an interplay between the text and image. The [[photomosaic]], whose tiny individual images form a mosaic when viewed from a distance, is a modern analogue.
== Motivation == {{see also|Calligram}} [[File:Caligrafia arabe pajaro.jpg|thumb|An Arabic [[calligram]] in the form of a peacock.]] There is a relationship between this form of art, employing both digital and analogic symbols, and the restrictions on images found in the [[Ten commandments#Traditional division and interpretation|second commandment]]. Micrography provides a unique solution to the visual artist who wishes to remain devout in observation of [[Jewish law]], by using only text, not images per se. As similar restrictions exist in certain [[Islam|Muslim]] societies, this solution has been adapted in [[Islamic calligraphy]] to the [[Arabic alphabet]] as well.

{{Infobox person | name = Mitch Kapor | image = MitchKapor.jpg | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1950|11|1}} | birth_place = [[Brooklyn, New York]], USA | other_names = | spouse = Ellen M. Poss (divorced)
[[Freada Kapor Klein]] | education = [[Yale University]] (B.A., 1971)
Beacon College of Boston (M.S., 1978)
[[MIT Sloan School of Management]] | known_for = [[Lotus 1-2-3]] and co-founder of The [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]] | occupation = Entrepreneur | module = {{Listen|embed=yes|filename=Mitch Kapor voice.ogg|title=Mitch Kapor's voice|type=speech|description=[[:File:Mitch Kapor voice.ogg|Recorded November 2014]]}} | children = 2 }} '''Mitchell David Kapor''' ({{IPAc-en|audio=En-Mitch Kapor.ogg|'|k|eɪ|p|ɔːr|}} {{respell|KAY|por}}; born November 1, 1950{{cite web | url=http://www.kapor.com/bio/ | title=Mitchell Kapor: Biography | publisher=Kapor.com}}{{cite web | url=https://www.computerhope.com/people/mitchell_kapor.htm | title=Mitchell Kapor}}) is an American entrepreneur best known for his work as an application developer in the early days of the personal computer software industry, later founding [[Lotus Software|Lotus]], where he was instrumental in developing the [[Lotus 1-2-3]] spreadsheet. He left Lotus in 1986. In 1990 with [[John Perry Barlow]] and [[John Gilmore (activist)|John Gilmore]], he co-founded the [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]], and served as its chairman until 1994. In 2003, Kapor became the founding chair of the [[Mozilla Foundation]], creator of the open source web browser [[Firefox]]. Kapor has been an investor in the personal computing industry, and supporter of social causes via Kapor Capital[https://www.kaporcapital.com/ Kapor Capital] and the Kapor Center.[https://www.kaporcenter.org/ Kapor Center] Kapor and his wife, [[Freada Kapor Klein]], invest in social impact tech startups that seek to narrow gaps in opportunity and access for underrepresented communities and attempt to eliminate barriers to full participation across the tech ecosystem. Kapor and Klein take a comprehensive approach to removing barriers in education and the workplace for all and fixing the leaks at every stage of the tech pipeline. Kapor serves on the board of SMASH, [http://www.smashprogram.org/ SMASH] a non-profit founded by Klein to help underrepresented scholars hone their [[Science, technology, engineering, and mathematics|STEM]] knowledge while building the networks and skills for careers in tech and the sciences.{{cite news | title=Oakland’s Kapors spend $40 million to help diversify tech world | url=https://www.sfgate.com/business/article/Oakland-s-Kapors-spend-40-million-to-help-6422693.php | first=Joe | last=Garofoli | work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] | date=August 3, 2015}}{{cite news | title=Tech power couple Mitch Kapor and Freada Kapor Klein give $40 million to make tech industry more diverse | url=https://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/blog/2015/08/mitch-kapor-freada-tech-diversity-philanthropy-40m.html | first=Jahna | last=Berry | work=[[American City Business Journals]] | date=August 5, 2015}}{{cite news | title=Mitchell Kapor seeks to meld business, social good | url=https://www.sfgate.com/news/article/Mitchell-Kapor-seeks-to-meld-business-social-good-4759003.php | first=Caleb | last=Garling | work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] | date=August 24, 2013}} ==Early life and education== Kapor was born to a [[American Jews|Jewish]] family{{Cite web|last= Wall |first=Alix |authorlink= |title= Meet the Oakland philanthropists trying to diversify the tech world |publisher=[[J. The Jewish News of Northern California]]|date=November 2, 2017 |url=https://www.jweekly.com/2017/11/02/meet-oakland-philanthropists-trying-diversify-tech-world/ |accessdate=}} in [[Brooklyn, New York]], and raised in [[Freeport, New York]] on Long Island, where he graduated from high school in 1967. He received a B.A. from [[Yale College]] in 1971 and studied psychology, linguistics, and computer science in an interdisciplinary major, also attending the Boston-based Beacon College, which had a satellite campus in Washington, D.C. at the time. He began but did not complete a master's degree at the [[MIT Sloan School of Management]] but later served on the faculty of the [[MIT Media Lab]] and the [[University of California, Berkeley School of Information]]. ==Career== ===Lotus=== Lotus was founded in 1982 by partners Mitch Kapor and [[Jonathan Sachs]] with backing from [[Benjamin M. Rosen|Ben Rosen]]. Lotus' first product was presentation software for the [[Apple II]] known as Lotus Executive Briefing System. Kapor founded Lotus after leaving his post as head of development at [[VisiCorp]], the distributors of the [[Visicalc]] [[spreadsheet]], and selling all his rights to VisiPlot and VisiTrend to VisiCorp. Shortly after Kapor left Visi-Corp, he and Sachs produced an integrated spreadsheet and graphics program. Even though IBM and VisiCorp had a collaboration agreement whereby Visi-Calc was being shipped simultaneously with the PC, Lotus had a clearly superior product. Lotus released [[Lotus 1-2-3]] on January 26, 1983. The name referred to the three ways the product could be used, as a spreadsheet, graphics package, and [[database manager]]. In practice the latter two functions were less often used, but 1-2-3 was the most powerful spreadsheet program available. Lotus was almost immediately successful, becoming the world's third largest microcomputer software company in 1983 with $53 million in sales in its first year,{{cite news | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kC4EAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA80&pg=PA80#v=onepage&q&f=false | title=Company Strategies Boomerang | work=InfoWorld | date=1984-04-02 | last=Caruso | first=Denise | pages=80–83}} compared to its business plan forecast of $1 million in sales. Jerome Want says: :Under founder and CEO Mitch Kapor, Lotus was a company with few rules and fewer internal bureaucratic barriers.... Kapor decided that he was no longer suited to running a company, and [in 1986] he replaced himself with [[Jim Manzi]].{{cite book|author=Jerome H. Want|title=Corporate Culture: Illuminating the Black Hole|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sWrelIr4pWsC&pg=PA55|year=2007|page=55}} ===Digital rights activism=== Kapor was extensively involved in initiatives that created the modern Internet. He co-founded the [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]] in 1990 and served as its chairman until 1994. EFF defends civil liberties in the digital world and works to ensure that rights and freedoms are enhanced and protected as our use of technology grows.{{cite news | title=Where Is the Digital Highway Really Heading? | url=https://www.wired.com/1993/03/kapor-on-nii/ | work=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] | date=March 1, 1993}}{{cite news | title=Mitch Kapor: Civilizing Cyberspace | url=https://www.rollingstone.com/culture/features/civilizing-cyberspace-19930610 | first=Jeff | last=Goodall | work=[[Rolling Stone]] | date=June 10, 1993}}{{cite news | title=Defending liberties in high-tech world | url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/13718446/ns/technology_and_science-tech_and_gadgets/t/defending-liberties-high-tech-world/ | first=ANICK | last=JESDANUN | agency=[[Associated Press]] | publisher=[[MSNBC]] | date=July 5, 2006}}{{Cite news | title=Mitch Kapor Backs Open Source Software For Simplifying Internet TV | url=https://www.informationweek.com/mitch-kapor-backs-open-source-software-for-simplifying-internet-tv/d/d-id/1035796 | first=Antone | last=Gonsalves | work=[[InformationWeek]] | date=September 6, 2005}} Kapor attended the first [[Wikimania]] in 2005.{{cite book | last1=Lih | first1=Andrew | authorlink=Andrew Lih | title=[[The Wikipedia Revolution: How a Bunch of Nobodies Created the World's Greatest Encyclopedia]] | date=2009 | publisher=Aurum | location=London | isbn=9781845134730 | oclc=280430641 | page=8 | quote=Mitch Kapor, founder of Lotus Development Corporation, made the trip on his own time.}} ===Investments=== Kapor was the founding investor in [[UUNET]], one of the first and the largest early Internet service provider; of [[RealNetworks|Real Networks]], the Internet’s first streaming media company; and of [[Linden Lab]], maker of the first successful virtual world, [[Second Life]]. He was also founding chair of the [[Commercial Internet eXchange]] (CIX). In 2003, Kapor became the founding chair of the [[Mozilla Foundation]], creator of the open source web browser [[Firefox]]. Kapor serves on the advisory board of the [[Sunlight Foundation]].{{cite web | url=https://sunlightfoundation.com/about/board/ | title=Board and Advisory Board | publisher=[[Sunlight Foundation]]}} In May 2009, after founder [[Susan P. Crawford]] had joined the Obama administration, Kapor took over chairmanship of [[OneWebDay]] - the "Earth Day for the internet". In 1996, the [[Computer History Museum]] named him a Museum Fellow "for his development of Lotus 1-2-3, the first major software application for the IBM PC."{{cite web | title=Mitch Kapor 1996 Fellow | url=http://www.computerhistory.org/fellowawards/hall/mitch-kapor/ | publisher=[[Computer History Museum]]}} He founded the Mitchell Kapor Foundation to support his philanthropic interests in environmental health. As an active [[angel investor]], Kapor participated in the initial rounds of [[Dropcam]], [[Twilio]], [[Asana (software)|Asana]], Cleanify, and [[Uber]]. ===Kapor Center and Kapor Capital=== Kapor founded the Kapor Center in 2000 as an institution focused on tech inclusion and social impact.{{cite web | title=Mitchell Kapor Foundation | url=https://www.guidestar.org/profile/94-3330604 | publisher=GuideStar}} The institution's mission is to invest in social and financial capital in vital non-profit organizations.{{cite news | title=Kapors pledge $40 million investment in tech diversity | url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/2015/08/04/mitch-kapor-freada-kapor-klein-tech-diversity-40-million-investment-pledge-white-house-demo-day/31069481/ | work=[[USA TODAY]] | date=August 4, 2015}} As part of the Kapor Center, Kapor Capital is its venture capital arm.{{cite web | title=Company Overview of Kapor Capital | url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=112164205 | publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.]]}} The venture capital firm has been investing since 2009, including early angel round investments in Uber.{{cite web | title=Kapor Capital - Investments | url=https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/kapor-capital/investments/investments_list | publisher=[[TechCrunch]]}} As of 2018, Kapor Capital has made over 160 investments, primarily in information technology seed stage startups, with a particular focus on diversity.{{cite web | title=Who We Are - Kapor Capital | url=http://www.kaporcapital.com/who-we-are/ | website=Kapor Capital}} Since 2016, the Kapor Center for Social Impact, Kapor Capital, and [http://www.smashprogram.org/ SMASH] have been located in the Uptown neighborhood of Oakland, CA.{{cite web | title=Kapor Center seeks to diversify tech while promoting Oakland Uptown Neighborhood | url=http://www.ktvu.com/news/kapor-center-seeks-to-diversify-tech-while-promoting-oakland-uptown-neighborhood | website=Fox 2 KTVU | date=July 20, 2016}} ===Diversity in technology=== In August 2015, Mitch and Freada announced they would invest $40 million over three years to accelerate their work to make the tech ecosystem more inclusive.{{cite news | url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/2015/08/04/mitch-kapor-freada-kapor-klein-tech-diversity-40-million-investment-pledge-white-house-demo-day/31069481/ | title=Kapors pledge $40 million investment in tech diversity | first=Jessica | last=Guynn | work=[[USA TODAY]] | date=August 4, 2015}}{{cite web | title=40 Diverse People In Tech Who Made Big Moves In 2015 | url=https://techcrunch.com/gallery/40-diverse-people-in-tech-2015/slide/16/ | publisher=[[TechCrunch]]}} In addition to his roles at Kapor Capital and Kapor Center, Mitch currently serves on the Board of [http://www.smashprogram.org/ SMASH], whose mission is to enhance equal opportunity in education and the workplace, and sits on the Advisory Board of Generation Investment Management, a firm whose vision is to embed sustainability into the mainstream capital markets.{{cite news | title=Let's Celebrate 2015 as a Year of Progress in Tech Inclusion | url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/future_tense/2015/12/29/_2015_was_a_year_of_progress_in_tech_inclusion.html | first=Brooke | last=Hunter | work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] | date=December 29, 2015 | issn=1091-2339}}{{cite news | title=The (Planet-Saving, Capitalism-Subverting, Surprisingly Lucrative) Investment Secrets of Al Gore | url=https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2015/11/the-planet-saving-capitalism-subverting-surprisingly-lucrative-investment-secrets-of-al-gore/407857/ | first=JAMES | last=FALLOWS | work=[[The Atlantic]] | date=November 2015}} ==Personal life== He is married to [[Freada Kapor Klein]] and resides in [[Oakland, California|Oakland]] and [[Healdsburg, California|Healdsburg]], [[California]].{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/05/04/fashion/oakland-california-brooklyn-by-the-bay.html | title=Oakland: Brooklyn by the Bay | first=Matt | last=Haber | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=May 2, 2014}}{{subscription required}} Both served on the Board of Trustees of the [[Summer Science Program]] from 2004 to 2006. {{Infobox institute |image = Patanjali_yogpeeth_entrance.jpg |image_name = Patanjali Yogpeeth |image_size = |image_alt = |caption = Entrance to Patanjali Yogpeeth |latin_name = |motto = |founder = [[Ramdev|Baba Ramdev]], [[Balkrishna|Acharya Balkrishna]] |established = 2006 |mission = |focus = Yoga, Ayurveda and medical aid |president = |chairman = Acharya Balkrishna |head_label = |head = |faculty = |adjunct_faculty = |staff = |key_people = Baba Ramdev |budget = |endowment = |debt = |num_members = |subsidiaries = |owner = Divya Yog Mandir (Trust) |non-profit_slogan = |former_name = |location = |city = [[Haridwar]] |state = [[Uttarakhand]] |province = |country = [[India]] |coor = |address = |website = [http://www.divyayoga.com/ Divya Yog Mandir (Trust)] |dissolved = |footnotes = }} '''Patanjali Yogpeeth''' in [[Haridwar]], [[Uttarakhand]], is one of the largest [[yoga]] institutes in India, possibly the whole world. Named after the Rishi [[Patanjali]], the institute is [[Ramdev|Baba Ramdev]]'s flagship project. Its purpose is to practise and research and develop yoga and [[ayurveda]], as well as manufacture ayurvedic medicines. It is also the home of the University of Patanjali. Acharya [[Balkrishna]] is the General Secretary of Patanjali Yogpeeth.<ref>[http://www.jagran.com/news/national-jasoda-ben-is-in-ramdev-ashram-11258576.html "जसोदा बेन की पतंजलि योगपीठ में मौजूदगी को आश्रम ने नकारा"] Jagran.com, 23 April 2014</ref><ref>[http://www.dehradun.amarujala.com/news/politics-dun/baba-ramdev-in-swachh-bharat-campaign-hindi-news/ "बेकार नहीं जाएगा मोदी का बाबा रामदेव पर भरोसा"] Amarujala, 2 October 2014</ref><ref>[http://www.indoamerican-news.com/?p=31959 "Patanjali Yogpeeth Held 3-day Yoga Workshop in Houston"] Indo American News, 5 March 2015</ref>
Located on the [[Haridwar]]-[[Delhi]] highway at [[Kankhal]], very near to [[Roorkee]], Patanjali Yogpeeth offers treatments for all and has residential accommodation. Pantanjali Yogpeeth is about 20 km from [[Haridwar]] at [[Kankhal]] and about 15 km from [[Roorkee]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.merinews.com/article/patanjali-yog-peeth-to-promote-ayurveda-in-himachal/15714473.shtml |title=Patanjali Yog Peeth to promote Ayurveda in Himachal |publisher=Merinews.com |date=2009-02-28 |accessdate=2012-08-28}}</ref><ref>[http://www.tribuneindia.com/news/uttarakhand/thousands-take-part-in-sanyas-week-at-patanjali-yogpeeth/58017.html 'Thousands take part in ‘sanyas week’ at Patanjali Yogpeeth'] The Tribune, 25 March 2015</ref>
==University of Patanjali== Patanjali Yogpeeth comprises two campuses, named Patanjali Yogpeeth - I and Patanjali Yogpeeth - II respectively.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://haridwarcity.in/patanjali-yogpeeth-haridwar/ |title=Patanjali Yogpeeth Haridwar |publisher=Haridwar City |accessdate=26 July 2015}}</ref>
===Patanjali Yogpeeth - I=== [[File:Patanjali_yogpeeth_mainbldg.jpg|thumb|Patanjali Yogpeeth I, Main Building (Sadbhawana)]] This first Yogpeeth campus was commissioned on 6 April 2006.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.divyayoga.com/divya-yog-mandir/a-campuses/pantanjali-yogpeeth-i.html |title=Patanjali Yogpeeth - I |publisher=Divya Yog Mandir (Trust) |accessdate=26 July 2015}}</ref>
* '''Patanjali Ayurveda College'''. In 2010, this study and research facility was commissioned as part of the university and has 122 students as of 2013. Inside the Campus library is a special area dedicated to the research of [[yoga]] and [[ayurveda]]. Various ancient books are being restored and digitized.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}}
===Patanjali Yogpeeth - II=== This second Yogpeeth campus was inaugurated in April 2009.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.divyayoga.com/patanjali-yog-peeth/a-campuses/patanjali-yogpeeth-ii.html |title=Patanjali Yogpeeth - II |publisher=Divya Yog Mandir (Trust) |accessdate=26 July 2015}}</ref>
* '''YogBhavan''' Patanjali Yog Bhawan is a huge auditorium of 200,000 sq. ft. where thousands of participants practice yoga, [[pranayama]] and [[meditation]] together. * '''Shradhalayam''' is a 60,000 sq. ft. air conditioned auditorium. * '''Panchkarma & Shatkarma Centre''' is a 40,000 sq. ft. centre where up to about 1,000 people can perform and participate in [[panchakarma]] and [[shatkarma]] therapy.
==Social responsibility== Patanjali Yogpeeth Trust, a non-profit organisation started by Swami [[Ramdev]], aims to carry out welfare activities in the spheres of health care, education and other [[Socioeconomics|socio-economic]] activities. Patanjali drives its [[Social responsibility]] initiatives through Patanjali Yogpeeth Trust.<ref>{{citation|publisher=LinkedIn|url=https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/business-plan-marketingmeet-indias-new-fmcg-giant-divya-vangipuram|title=No Business Plan. No Marketing.Meet India’s new FMCG giant, Patanjali|date=1 June 2015}}</ref>
